verse: When Saul got back from fighting off the Philistines, he heard that David was in the desert around En-Gedi.
Saul led three thousand of Israel’s best soldiers out to look for David and his men near Wild Goat Rocks at En-Gedi.
There were some sheep pens along the side of the road, and one of them was built around the entrance to a cave. Saul went into the cave to relieve himself.
They whispered to David, “The Lord told you he was going to let you defeat your enemies and do whatever you want with them. This must be the day the Lord was talking about.”
Afterwards, David was sorry that he had even done that,
and he told his men, “Stop talking foolishly. We’re not going to attack Saul. He’s my king, and I pray that the Lord will keep me from doing anything to harm his chosen king.”
Soon, David also got up and left the cave. “Your Majesty!” he shouted from a distance.
“David, my son—is that you?” Saul asked. Then he started crying
So David promised, and Saul went home. David and his men returned to their hideout.
